description:
Fonsecaea pedrosoi CBS 271.37 is a species of dematiaceous (dark-pigmented) fungus that belongs to the genus Fonsecaea. It is a causative agent of chromoblastomycosis, a chronic and progressive subcutaneous mycosis characterized by the formation of verrucous, tumor-like lesions on the skin and underlying tissues.

The strain Fonsecaea pedrosoi CBS 271.37 was originally isolated from a human case of chromoblastomycosis in Brazil. This strain is commonly used in research and diagnostic studies related to chromoblastomycosis.

Morphologically, F. pedrosoi CBS 271.37 produces dark-colored, septate hyphae and a variety of asexual spore structures, including sclerotic bodies (also known as muriform or medlar bodies), which are the diagnostic hallmark of chromoblastomycosis. The fungus grows slowly on various culture media and exhibits a characteristic colonial morphology.

Genetically, F. pedrosoi CBS 271.37 has been studied extensively, and its genome sequence is available, providing insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying its pathogenicity and potential targets for antifungal drug development.

Overall, the detailed study of this specific strain, Fonsecaea pedrosoi CBS 271.37, has contributed to our understanding of the epidemiology, diagnosis, and treatment of chromoblastomycosis, a neglected tropical disease with significant public health implications.
